parameter.name: Should Do not provide calcium supplementation

extension.valueString: Population with low dietary calcium intake

/*
  Description: Women in the population are likely to have low dietary
    calcium intake (less than 900 mg of calcium per day)
*/
define "Population with low dietary calcium intake":
  true
Should Do not provide calcium supplementation

/*
IF "Population with low dietary calcium intake" = FALSE
*/
define "Should Do not provide calcium supplementation":
  Config."Population with low dietary calcium intake" = true

/*
  Description: Vitamin A deficiency is a severe public health problem
    if 5% or more of women in a population have a history of night
    blindness in their most recent pregnancy in the previous 3–5 years
    that ended in a live birth, or if 20% or more of pregnant women
    have a serum retinol level below 0.70 µmol/L
*/
define "Population with vitamin A deficiency":
  true

/*
IF "Population with vitamin A deficiency" = TRUE
*/
define "Should Provide vitamin A supplementation":
  Config."Population with vitamin A deficiency" = true

/*
IF "Population with low dietary calcium intake" = TRUE
*/
define "Should Provide calcium supplementation":
  Config."Population with low dietary calcium intake" = true

name: ANCDT26
title: ANC.DT.26 Calcium and vitamin A supplementation
description: Depending on the population, additional calcium and/or vitamin A supplements maybe required

coding.display: "Population with low dietary calcium intake" = TRUE AND/OR IF "Population with vitamin A deficiency" = TRUE

action.title: ANC.DT.26 Calcium and vitamin A supplementation

trigger.name: IF "Population with low dietary calcium intake" = TRUE AND/OR IF "Population with vitamin A deficiency" = TRUE

action.title: Provide calcium supplementation
action.textEquivalent:
In populations with low dietary calcium intake, daily calcium supplementation (1.5–2.0 g oral elemental calcium) is recommended for pregnant women to reduce the risk of pre-eclampsia. 

Dietary counselling of pregnant women should promote adequate calcium intake through locally available, calcium-rich foods.

– Divide the total dose into three doses, preferably taken at meal-time.
– Iron and calcium should preferably be administered several hours apart rather than concomitantly.

Please refer to calcium sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

documentation.label: WHO ANC recommendations (2016): A.3. Calcium supplements (3)

expression.description: IF "Population with low dietary calcium intake" = TRUE

action.title: 1.5 g ≤ "Amount of calcium supplements provided" ≤ 2 g
Do not provide calcium supplementation
action.textEquivalent:
Dietary counselling of pregnant women should promote adequate calcium intake through locally available, calcium-rich foods.

Please refer to calcium sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

documentation.label: WHO ANC recommendations (2016): A.3. Calcium supplements (3)

expression.description: IF "Population with low dietary calcium intake" = FALSE
expression.expression: Should Do not provide calcium supplementation

action.title: Provide vitamin A supplementation
action.textEquivalent:
Give a dose of up to 10,000 IU vitamin A per day, or a weekly dose of up to 25,000 IU.

A single dose of a vitamin A supplement greater than 25,000 IU is not recommended as its safety is uncertain. Furthermore, a single dose of a vitamin A supplement greater than 25,000 IU might be teratogenic if consumed between day 15 and day 60 from conception.

Please refer to vitaminA sources listed below for additional guidance that can be provided.

documentation.label: WHO ANC recommendations (2016): A.4. Vitamin A supplements (3)

expression.description: IF "Population with vitamin A deficiency" = TRUE

action.title: "Amount of vitamin A supplementation provided" ≤ 10 000 IU
Type of vitamin A supplement provided" = "Daily"
